questions.text: A 43-year-old man presented with headache and blurred vision for a few weeks. Investigation showed serum prolactin of 21 500mU/l. On further questioning he admitted loss of interest in sexual intercourse over the past few months and general feelings of lethargy. Computerised tomography (CT) brain scan showed a large pituitary mass encroaching on the optic chiasm with evidence of midline shift. What is the next appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
It is likely that this man has a macroprolactinoma, characterised by the markedly raised prolactin level and the symptoms of tiredness and lack of sexual interest. Symptoms of macroprolactinoma include galactorrhoea and amenorrhoea in women, and hypogonadism and impotence in men. Macroprolactinomas may also be associated with headaches, visual field defects and generalised hypopituitarism. In this case, the presence of visual disturbance and midline shift seen on the CT necessitate early surgery. Surgery via the trans-sphenoidal route is the treatment of choice; very large tumours may occasionally have to be removed via an open transfrontal approach. Patients should also be assessed prior to surgery for hypocortisolism, and appropriate replacement therapy with corticosteroids begun if necessary. Removal of adenoma is preferable to complete hypophysectomy, as other pituitary functions may recover after adenomectomy

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:373 Pg:2677

choices.text: Reduced expression of renal aquaporin channels

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man drinks 10 pints of strong beer after which He suffers from polyuria and passes large volumes of urine. His blood results are shown below
Na+ 145 mmol/l
K+ 4.4 mmol/l
Urea 55 mg/dl
Creatinine 1.98 mg/dl
Which of the following is the most likely underlying process?
questions.solution:
Here we see reduced expression of renal aquaporin channels, leading to increased water excretion. Around 30 mutations of aquaporin 2 have been identified which are related to diabetes insipidus. They affect the ability of the kidney to concentrate urine in response to vasopressin. Other aquaporin mutations are involved in the pathophysiology of diseases such as muscular dystrophy and Sjogren’s syndrome.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:374 Pg:2685

questions.text: You review a 26-year-old woman who came to your clinic with her husband. They wish to start a family, and wants to have your suggestion as he is worried that she has a history of heart disease. Which of the following cardiovascular conditions is an absolute contra-indication to pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Whilst increased monitoring is recommended in patients with mitral valve prolapse or congenital bicuspid aortic valve, neither are absolute contraindications to pregnancy. Small atrial septal defects often remain undetected for many years, and previously repaired patent ductus arteriosis should not impair pregnancy. Primary pulmonary hypertension rapidly worsens in pregnancy however, and patients are advised not to get pregnant.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:466 Pg:3442

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman with two episodes of sudden-onset limb paralysis at night-time over the last 4 months. She describes waking shortly after falling asleep and being aware of an inability to move her limbs or to speak, associated with a feeling of suffocation lasting for about a minute. Her father recently died from an intracerebral haemorrhage during sleep. She has no other symptoms other than daytime sleepiness, which she puts down to looking after her two young children. There are no abnormalities on examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This woman is describing sleep paralysis. It reflects the atonia of REM sleep. Awareness is preserved during the attack, which heightens the sense of terror and anxiety, especially if a feeling of suffocation is present (although the respiratory muscles are only ever mildly affected in comparison to the limbs). Sleep paralysis may be isolated or occur in the context of narcolepsy, in which it affects 15-45% of patients.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Pg:171

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy presents to you. Most recently he has suffered a respiratory tract infection and he is very distressed that on going to the bathroom he is urinating frank blood. The only history of note is microscopic haematuria diagnosed in childhood. Renal biopsy with histological staining is consistent with a diagnosis of Alport's syndrome. Which of the following other features is likely to be present?
questions.solution:
Alport's syndrome is the combination of nephritis and sensorineural deafness. It follows either an autosomal recessive or an x-linked pattern of inheritance. The condition is caused by abnormalities in Type IV collagen. Microscopic haematuria always presents within the first decade of life, and patients may present with acute macroscopic haematuria post upper respiratory tract infection. Other associated conditions apart from nephritis and deafness include anterior lenticonus, retinopathy and posterior corneal dystrophy. Angiotensin inhibitors may have a role to play in reducing proteinuria and slowing progression of renal disease.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:308 Pg:2146-2147

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with a resting tremor of his right arm and a diagnosis of idiopathic Parkinson's disease is made. Which one of the following drugs is most likely to help his tremor?
questions.solution:
Co-careldopa may be associated with worsening of the end-of-use phenomena and dyskinesia in periods between doses. Selegiline may also precipitate worsening of dyskinesia. Amantadine has only modest anti-parkinsonian effects. The treatment that may produce the best improvement in tremor in idiopathic Parkinson's disease is benzhexol, although it has little effect on bradykinesia. It is contraindicated in patients with a history of urinary retention and angle-closure glaucoma, and in patients with untreated prostatic symptoms.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:427 Pg:3132

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought to the clinic. He is a long term user of intravenous heroin. Over the past few days he has become confused and aggressive and has suffered a fit. Investigations reveal ring lesions on contrast CT scan, his CD4 count is 45/ mm3 (normal >500) and an HIV test is positive. You suspect he has toxoplasmosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy for him?
questions.solution:
Sulphadiazine and pyrimethamine is seen as combination therapy of choice for patients with toxoplasmosis in the setting of HIV infection. Sulphadiazine may however be associated with adverse effects (commonly rash) in up to 40% of users, as such clindamycin may be substituted, clarithromycin or azithromycin may be additional alternatives but used in combination with pyrimethamine. Whilst anti-retroviral therapy may be associated with a decreased viral load and improved CD4 count, there is limited data on discontinuing long term maintainence therapy against toxoplasmosis, therefore most patients continue permanent therapy at a lower dose.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Pg:1016, 1614

questions.text: A 34-year-old man returns from a cruise on the river in Egypt. During the trip he had some local food from the various stops along the river. For a few days before coming home, and since his return he has suffered from diarrhoea which floats on the surface of the toilet bowl and is hard to flush away. He has also noticed that his abdomen feels very bloated, and the diarrhoea occasionally contains blood. His partner complains that he has increased flatulence that smells disgusting. A fresh stool sample is obtained which appears to contain some cysts. Which of the following represent the most likely infective cause?
questions.solution:
This patient has a diarrhoeal illness caused by giardia lamblia, a flagellate protozoan water borne infection. It is common to the middle east, trophozoytes and cysts may be seen in a fresh stool sample, otherwise treatment is often empirical. Lactose intolerance persists in a significant number of patients post infection, symptoms of which do resemble continued giardiasis. Treatment of giardiasis is either with a one off dose of tinidazole, or a short course of metronidazole.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Pg:261, 262, 1615-1617

questions.text: A 43-year-old man was diagnosed with new onset AF after complaining of palpitations. An ECG confirmed atrial fibrillation with a ventricular rate of 85/minute, and an ECHO did not reveal any significant structural heart disease. On advice of the hospital, he was given low molecular weight heparin and stabilised on warfarin, with an INR of 2.5. You arrange for him to be cardioverted a few weeks later and the procedure is successful. For how long is it recommended to continue his warfarin therapy according to current guidelines?
questions.solution:
Guidelines recommend warfarinisation for at least 3 weeks pre and for 4 weeks post cardioversion, aiming for a target INR of 2.5, although this can be allowed to drift up to an INR of 3 a few days prior to the procedure to minimise any risks of cancellation due to inadequate anti-coagulation. The period of 4 weeks post procedure is recommended because there is a high relapse rate in the first few weeks.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Pg:1884, 1710

choices.text: Human T-cell lymphotrophic virus type I (HTLV-I)

questions.text: A 28-year-old homosexual man has been diagnosed with anal carcinoma. Which pathogen is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
HHV8 is associated with Kaposi's sarcoma and body cavity (primary effusion) lymphoma in HIV. HTLV-I infection is associated with a 2-5% lifetime risk of acute T-cell lymphoma/leukaemia (ATLL). HPV is considered an aetiological agent in carcinoma of anal canal in homosexual men.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Pg:1370, 1451

choices.text: Pizotifen (for prophylaxis) and ergotamine (for the acute attacks)
Amitriptyline (for prophylaxis) and a triptan (for the acute attacks)
Methysergide (for prophylaxis) and a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) (for the acute attacks)
Regular daily non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) (for prophylaxis), increased during the acute attacks

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman has a disabling headache syndrome consisting of recurrent, severe, unilateral (either right or left) headaches twice a week lasting for 8 hours each. The pain is constant and associated with nausea and phonophobia. It has not responded to ibuprofen or paracetamol. The headaches are more common after physical exercise. She has identified no dietary triggers, and there is no family history of migraine. She is very worried about her increasing weight. Which of the following is a sensible treatment course?
questions.solution:
The history is most consistent with common migraine (migraine without aura). The frequency of the attacks justifies prophylaxis. Pizotifen is a reasonable first-line agent (5 HT2 receptor antagonist), but she is worried about her weight (pizotifen causes weight gain); and ergotamine is not commonly used for acute treatment nowadays. Methysergide is associated with pleural and retroperitoneal fibrosis, and is avoided in all but the most intractable cases. Regular analgesics predispose patients to the development of chronic daily headache, particularly those that contain opiates (like co-proxamol). This is very much the danger in the situation described, because her headaches are common and disabling and could lead to the use of large amounts of analgesia. The correct answer is B - amitriptyline is a reasonable first-choice prophylactic, and treatment with a triptan for the acute attack is justified in this patient because simple analgesia has failed. The tricyclic antidepressants may cause weight gain in some but the risk of this is lower than with pizotifen so it seems a reasonable choice in this case.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:422 Pg:3096-3102

questions.text: You see a 39-year-old woman with progressively increased shortness of breath and lethargy after the birth of her 1st child. You send her for some pulmonary function tests, including measurement of gas transfer. Which of the following gases is usually used for measurement of gas transfer?
questions.solution:
The DLCO (or diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide) is the standard method for measuring gas transfer from alveoli to red blood cells. DLCO is measured by looking at end-expiratory levels of CO after inspiring a small amount and breath holding. It is adjusted for haematocrit and alveolar volume. Conditions which affect the pulmonary vasculature and those which lead to pulmonary fibrosis affect the DLCO.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:279 Pg:1950

choices.text: Cigarette smoking is a known primary risk factor
Simian SV 40 is the most common cause
Loss of one copy of chromosome 22 is the most common karyotypic change in mesothelioma cell lines
Drainage of pleural effusion is never associated with tumour seeding along the track

questions.text: You review a 72-year-old former boilermaker. He has suffered increasing shortness of breath and vague right sided chest pain over the past few months. He has a history of smoking 30 cigarettes per day for 30 years. On examination he appears to have a large right sided pleural effusion. This is confirmed on chest x-ray. Pleural fluid evaluation reveals this to be an exudate and you suspect an underlying mesothelioma. Which of the following fit best with the pathophysiology of mesothelioma?
questions.solution:
Exposure to asbestosis is the primary risk factor associated with the development of mesothelioma. SV40 is a possible co-carcinogen, although exposure to SV40 alone is not thought to be associated with mesothelioma. Surgical cure is usually not possible, although pleurectomy or pneumonectomy may bring relief of symptoms. The role of cigarette smoking has been under much debate; a categorical link to increased risk of mesothelioma on top of asbestos exposure has not been proven.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Pg:659, 1978

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man presents to the clinic complaining of painful hands and fingers. On examination he has bilateral sausage shaped fingers and pain over the distal interphalangeal joints. His nails are also pitted. There is no other past medical history of note. His blood results are shown below.
Hb 14.0 g/dl
PLT 180 * 10*9/L
WCC 8.1 * 10*9/L
CRP46 mg/l
Rheumatoid factor negative
Na+ 140 mmol/l
K+ 5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 1 mg/dl
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The picture of symmetrical distal polyarthritis, dactylitis and nail pitting is very typical of psoriatic arthritis. Nail pitting may be the only visible sign of psoriasis and frank skin plaques do not necessarily have to be present. Most patients are rheumatoid factor negative, although case series report positive rheumatoid factor in 5-9% of patients. Initial treatment is with non-steroidals, although TNF-alpha plays an integral role in the pathogenesis of the disease, and anti-TNF alpha antibodies have joined a range of other second line therapies like sulphasalazine, methotrexate and cyclosporine in the management of the condition.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:355 Pg:2571, 2572

questions.text:
A 44-year-old alcoholic gentleman is admitted with pain, swelling and redness over the 1st MTP joint. On examination he has a number of tophi, and this is diagnosed as gout. He is started on allopurinol and discharged. 2 days later he returns complaining of pain and inflammation over the small joints of his hands, his wrists, ankles and knees. His temperature is 38.5°C. Bloods Hb 11.0g/dl
WCC 6.9 * 10*9/L
PLT 145 * 10*9/L
Na+ 138 mmol/l
K+ 4.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 0.8 mg/dl
Which of the following is the most likely cause of his presentation?
questions.solution:
Treatment of patients presenting with an acute exacerbation of gout using allopurinol alone may precipitate a severe acute attack including pyrexia. For this reason it is more usual to begin allopurinol in conjunction with an appropriate NSAID or to begin the NSAID a few days before allopurinol. Given that he is an alcoholic though the risks of using a NSAID may have been deemed too great. One possible alternative is colchicine, but patients find this difficult to tolerate on occasions due to diarrhoea.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:365 Pg:2632, 2633

questions.text: A 49-year-old non-smoking lady with asthma managed with fluticasone + salmeterol 50, 2 puffs BD and a BMI of 35 presents with 3 months progressive shortness of breath. Her lung function tests are as follows: FEV1 2.2 (87% predicted) Post salbutamol 2.3 FVC 3.4 (82% predicted) Post salbutamol 3.5 Transfer coefficient 55% What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This woman has morbid obesity and because of this is at risk of pulmonary emboli. Her FEV1 and FVC are relatively preserved; at least some of the reduction seen will be due to her obesity. She is a non-smoker so that COPD is unlikely, and there is no history of haemoptysis or other symptoms suggestive of a condition associated with pulmonary haemorrhage. The absence of chest pain and the slow increase in shortness of breath suggests that she has suffered multiple small pulmonary emboli

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:273 Pg:1911

questions.text: A 53-year-old-life-long smoker, who has worked for many years in a shipyard presents with a few months history of increasing breathlessness. On examination he has a BP of 145/85 mmHg and a pulse of 75/minute; his BMI is 31 and he also appears to have finger clubbing. Auscultation of the chest reveals bibasal inspiratory crackles. CXR is reported as showing evidence of pleural plaques Pulmonary function testing reveals a mixed obstructive/restrictive picture. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his breathlessness?
questions.solution:
Shipbuilding, car manufacture, boiler making and plumbing industries are all associated with risk of asbestosis exposure. Whilst he does indeed have asbestos related pleural plaques seen on CXR, plaques themselves are not thought to contribute to breathlessness. In contrast the findings on auscultation of the chest, coupled with the finger clubbing and the restrictive component seen on pulmonary function testing point towards asbestos related pulmonary fibrosis, or asbestosis.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:283 Pg:1997, 1978

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with gradually reducing vision in her left eye of two weeks duration. Visual acuity is 6/4 (right eye) and 6/36 (left eye). The left pupil reacts sluggishly and the consensual pupillary reaction in the right eye is also sluggish. Optic discs are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
As the optic discs appear normal, it may be tempting to pass off the alleged blurring as factitious. However, in retrobulbar neuritis it is said that 'the patient sees nothing and the doctor sees nothing'. As the inflammation is behind the optic nerve head (hence retrobulbar), as opposed to optic neuritis, the optic nerve head or optic disc appears normal. Optic nerve function, however, is affected in the same way in patients with optic and retrobulbar neuritis. Thus visual acuity will be reduced to a very variable degree, and an afferent pupillary defect will be apparent during the 'swinging flashlight test'. Colour vision will be reduced to a greater extent than might be predicted from visual acuity. Red desaturation - ie when red looks paler to one eye than the other - is a sensitive sign of optic nerve dysfunction. Visual field defects will occur (typically a central scotoma, but the type of defect varies). Retrobulbar neuritis has the same systemic implications as optic neuritis, in that an episode of optic or retrobulbar neuritis can contribute to a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis, if other neurological episodes separated in time and site occur. Holmes-Adie pupil is an idiopathic condition, typically affecting young women, presenting with an enlarged pupil that is poorly reactive to light and accommodation. Absent ankle jerks are a frequent association. A Holmes-Adie pupil causes no harm, except blurring vision when reading in some patients.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Pg:222

questions.text: In what type of dementia are both neurofibrillary tangles (NFTs) and senile plaques seen pathologically?
questions.solution:
Pick's disease has neither. NFTs, but not senile plaques, are seen in patients with the punchdrunk syndrome. Senile plaques, but not NFTs, are seen in Lewy body dementia. Lewy bodies are also seen pathologically in Lewy body dementia.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:423 Pg:3108, 3109

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with multiple dental problems presents to the Emergency department. Apart from an abscess on his toe for which he has been receiving flucloxacillin he has been relatively well. On examination he has splinter haemorrhages and looks anemic. You detect an aortic systolic murmur. Echocardiogram is suggestive of aortic valve endocarditis and blood cultures confirm Streptococcus viridans. In addition to IV benzylpenicillin which antibiotic would you prescribe?
questions.solution:
The standard regime for suspected viridans endocarditis would be benzylpenicillin IV together with gentamycin 1mg/kg/day. Ceftriaxone is an alternative in stable patients and has the advantage of being given once per day. In patients who are penicillin allergic vancomycin is a viable alternative. The most likely route for his infection is via dental infection. As long as S viridans endocarditis is appropriately managed, cure rates approach 98%.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Pg:926-930

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man with a 40 pack year smoking history presents to the clinic complaining of a chronic cough and haemoptysis. He has lost 4kg in weight recently. He has an abnormal chest x-ray consistent with bronchial carcinoma. Investigations; Hb 11.0 g/dl
WCC 6.1 * 10*9/L
PLT 352 * 10*9/L
ESR 65 mm/hr
Na+ 132 mmol/l
K+ 3.9 mmol/l
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dl
Bronchoscopy with transbronchial biopsy reveals adenocarcinoma of the bronchus You arrange a CT thorax. Which of the following would tend to rule out the possibility of a surgical cure?
questions.solution:
Pleural effusion implies pleural involvement; hence this precludes a surgical cure. FEV1 of less than 1.0 precludes surgery for bronchial carcinoma as not enough lung reserve would be present afterwards. Contralateral lymph node involvement implies distant spread and again precludes surgery. Horner’s syndrome is due to local nerve involvement and therefore does not exclude successful surgical excision of the primary tumour. Metastasis is usual at time of presentation in small cell carcinoma; therefore, patients are usually managed with a combination of radio- and chemotherapy.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th edition, Pg:2007, 659, 661

questions.text:
A 70-year-old lady with a history of one previous myocardial infarction presents to the Emergency department. She has sudden onset shortness of breath and palpitations which happened after her dinner a couple of hours earlier. A previous ECG from clinic a month earlier shows sinus rhythm. Medication includes ramipril 10mg daily, amlodipine 10mg daily and aspirin 75mg. On examination her blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg, pulse is 140/min irregular and she has evidence of LVF.
Bloods Hb 14.0 g/dl
WCC 6.7 * 10*9/L
PLT 190 * 10*9/L
Na+ 140 mmol/l
K+ 5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dl
ECG Fast atrial fibrillation, lateral ST depression Which of the following is the most appropriate medication to control her AF?
questions.solution:
Flecainide, whilst effective at cardioverting atrial fibrillation is contra-indicated in patients with a history of ischaemic heart disease since the CAST post infarct trial demonstrated increased mortality in patients treated with flecainide. Sotolol and verapamil are negatively inotropic and likely to worsen LVF. Digoxin would be effective at slowing the ventricular rate, but given that she was in sinus rhythm 1 month earlier, it would be a reasonable objective to attain sinus rhythm again. As such IV loading with amiodarone would appear to be the most appropriate option in this patient

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Principles, 20th edition, ch:246 pg:1749

questions.text: You are asked to see a 19-year-old woman in the Emergency department. She has been brought to the unit by her father who is concerned that she may have taken an overdose after being depressed about her mother who is dying of carcinoma of the breast. Which of the following may indicate that she has taken some of her mother's morphine sulphate pills
questions.solution:
Morphine sulphate has a number of side effects including nausea, vomiting, constipation, drowsiness and confusion. Psychological and physical dependence may occur. Other side effects include bronchospasm, angioedema, urinary retention, ureteric or biliary spasm, dry mouth, sweating, rash, facial flushing, vertigo, tachycardia, bradycardia, palpitations, orthostatic hypotension, hypothermia, restlessness, mood change, hallucinations, seizures (adults and children) and miosis, headache and allergic reactions (including anaphylaxis) and decreased libido or potency. Raised intracranial pressure occurs in some patients. Muscle rigidity may occur with high doses. Elevated liver enzymes may occur due to biliary sphincter constriction. Large doses can lead to respiratory depression, circulatory failure and coma.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:269, 446 Pg:1877, 3284-86

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, who is 8 weeks pregnant, has two episodes of convulsions. The decision is made to commence anti-epileptic drug treatment. She wants advice about the anti-epileptic drug associated with the lowest risk of congenital malformations. Which of the following would you most avoid?
questions.solution:
Evidence on the effect of anti-epileptic drugs in pregnancy is gradually being accumulated. There is a clear suggestion of increased risk associated with sodium valproate used as monotherapy. There is an approximately 6% rate of congenital major malformations (particularly neural tube defects and craniofacial abnormalities) with valproate, compared with a rate of around 2.5% for carbamazepine, 3.5% for phenytoin and 1.5% in the general population. This risk is even higher for patients taking valproate plus other AEDs. Valproate should be avoided in pregnancy if possible, with counselling given to all women of childbearing capacity who are prescribed AEDs.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles Of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:418 Pg:3064

questions.text: A type-2 diabetic patient presents with a blood pressure of 155/90 mmHg and microalbuminuria. Which would be the most appropriate choice of antihypertensive drug for this patient?
questions.solution:
Antihypertensive treatment retards the progression of diabetic nephropathy from its earliest stages, slowing the progression of microalbuminuria to overt proteinuria and the decline of glomerular filtration rate in established diabetic nephropathy. Treatment with angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors confers additional protection, but the control of blood pressure probably outweighs any specific effect of ACE inhibition. The evidence is stronger for type-1 than type-2 diabetes, but all patients with diabetic nephropathy should receive antihypertensive treatment that includes an ACE inhibitor. The blood pressure target is (in most cases) as low as is achievable, ideally less than 130/80 mmHg, or less than 125/75 mmHg when there is proteinuria greater than 1 g/24 H

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Principles, 20th edition, ch:308 pg:2144

questions.text: A 44-year-old TB patient on medication for a respiratory tract infection and constipation complains that his urine is stained orange-red. His contact lenses have also become discoloured. Which drug is most likely to cause this?
questions.solution:
Patients on rifampicin should be warned that their urine, tears and other secretions will develop a bright orange-red colour. Nelfinavir, a protease inhibitor, may be associated with haematuria and crystalluria due to renal-stone formation. B complex vitamins may darken the urine, but do not produce widespread changes in all body secretions. Erythromycin does not cause a change in urine colour.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th edition, Pg:1255, 1256

questions.text:
A 65 year old lady presents with malaise and weight loss, having been referred by the GP for investigation of anaemia. His investigations show :
Hb 8.0 g/dl MCV 105 fl
MCHC 33 g/dl (32-35) WCC 11 * 10^9/L
platelets 130 * 10^9/L urea 33 mg/dl
creatinine 0.90 mg/dl sodium 140 mmol/l
potassium 4 mmol/l bilirubin 1.02mg/dl
AST 28 U/l ALP 180 U/l
iron 50 mmol/l (14-29)
ferritin 550 μg/l (15-200)
Bone marrow aspirate shows increased haemosiderin, normoblastic hyperplasia and ringed red blood cells Which of the following is likely?
questions.solution:
In sideroblastic anaemia, there is increased bone marrow iron. This is reflected in the increased iron stores in ferritin and also haemosiderin and ringed premature red blood cells (sideroblasts) due to excess iron. Sideroblastic anaemia occurs due to an enzyme deficiency (ALA synthase 2 deficiency), alcohol, drugs (anti TB), myelodysplasia. Ringed sideroblasts in a case of myelodysplasia

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Principles, 20th edition pg:686, 687, 391-92

questions.text: A 36-year-old patient is investigated for his anaemia. A bone marrow biopsy shows a reduction of haematopoietic cells, a trephine biopsy shows mainly fatty bone marrow. Given the likely diagnosis, what is the most effective long term treatment if this problem persists without an obvious predisposing factor having been identified?
questions.solution:
Recolonisation of the aplastic bone marrow with normal stem cells from a suitable donor has long been considered the most rational treatment for aplastic anaemia. World-wide experience has shown that such transplants are the most effective treatment for very severe aplastic anaemia and severe aplastic anaemia in patients of suitable age. Patients up to the age of 55 years and, in certain instances, older, with very severe aplastic anaemia should be considered for stem-cell transplantation. Children and young adults with severe aplastic anaemia should be offered transplantation as the first choice.

The problems of stem-cell transplantation for aplastic anaemia are the same as for other conditions, namely graft rejection and graftversus-host disease. Graft rejection may be increased by sensitisation to multiple blood transfusions, so transplants are best carried out early, once the diagnosis has been confirmed, the severity established and a suitable donor identified. Stem cells for transplantation may be obtained from the bone marrow or from the peripheral blood following mobilisation of the stem cells from the marrow by granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF). Peripheral blood stem-cell transplants lead to a quicker recovery of peripheral blood counts (at about 14 days compared with 20) but may cause more chronic graft-versus-host disease.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Principles, 20th edition, pg:816, 820-21, 727-28

questions.text: Which of the following is an acute porphyria?
questions.solution:
The acute porphyrias include acute intermittent porphyria and variegate porphyria. These are rare genetic errors of haem biosynthesis. Accumulation of porphyrin precursors (porphobilinogen and daminolaevulinic acid) cause neuronal and visceral crises. The acute intermittent type is inherited as an autosomal-dominant, although penetrance is low and around one-third of cases are due to mutations. The urinary porphobilinogen level is raised during an acute attack, but only 50% of samples will turn red on standing. Faecal levels of porphyrin are normal in patients with the acute intermittent type, unlike the variegate form. Variegate porphyria is also inherited as an autosomal-dominant and is associated with photosensitivity causing blistering.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Principles, 20th edition, ch:409 pg:2994, 2995

questions.text: A 20-year-old man from a family of travellers presents to the Emergency department. He has suffered a sudden deterioration in vision. Additional past medical history of note includes bilateral shoulder dislocation. On examination he is tall and thin with a high arched palate. He appears to have suffered a lens dislocation Which of the following genes is most likely to be abnormal?
questions.solution:
This man has Marfan’s, his late presentation to medical services perhaps being explained by the fact that he is from a travelling family. The history of joint and lens dislocation, and his Marfanoid habitus is strongly supportive of the diagnosis. Marfan’s occurs due to a defect in the fibrillin-1 gene, which codes for fibrillin, an essential building block of microfibrils, which are a component of the suspensory ligament of the lens and other tissues with elasticity such as the aorta. Collagen gene defects are associated with Ehlers Danlos syndrome.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Principles, 20th edition, ch:406 pg:2975, 2976

questions.text: A 73-year-old man who complains of lethargy and tiredness. Recent haemoglobin was low at 10.1 g/dl and he had a macrocytosis. Further investigation reveals no evidence of haematological malignancy, but screening does reveal folic acid deficiency. Which of the following foods contains the largest proportion of folic acid?
questions.solution:
150 g of liver contains around 180 mg of folic acid, a banana 20 mg, a papaya 25 mg, a cup of spinach 60 mg and a cup of baked beans around 60 mg. Folic acid requirements increase during pregnancy and lactation, causes of deficiency may be alcohol abuse, malabsorption, kidney dialysis and liver disease. Coeliac disease via a process of villous atrophy and small bowel resection may lead to decreased area for folic acid absorption and subsequent folate deficiency.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Pg:700, 703, 690

questions.text:
A 70-year-old woman presents to the preoperative orthopaedic clinic prior to hip replacement. She has suffered a myocardial infarction 4 years earlier and is managed with aspirin 75mg daily, ramipril 10mg daily and atorvastatin 40mg daily. There is no history of angina but she is only able to walk around 50 yards. On examination she looks well, her BP is 145/80 mmHg with a pulse of 75/minute.
Bloods; Hb 14.0 g/dl
WCC 5.9 * 10*9/L
PLT 180 * 10*9/L
Na+ 140 mmol/l
K+ 5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dl
Which of the following is the most appropriate investigation to assess her suitability for surgery from the point of view of her cardiovascular status?
questions.solution:
Dobutamine stress echo simulates the effect of exercise on the heart in patients who are unable to undertake a stress test. Dobutamine is given via IV infusion, and ECG monitoring with Echocardiography is undertaken both at rest and at the point of maximal stimulation. Patients are recommended to discontinue beta-blockade if possible for around 3 days prior to the procedure, as the negatively inotropic and chronotropic effects of beta blockade can blunt the effects of the dobutamine infusion.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:236 Pg:1685

choices.text: Encourage her to raise the head of the bed
Add an anti-acid to her regime

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman has a 12 year history of asthma. There is also a history of acid reflux, where she reports symptoms of waterbrash and burning in her throat nearly every night. She has suffered 3 lower respiratory tract infections in the past year despite long term continuous treatment with 40mg omeprazole. Her BMI is 28. Upper GI endoscopy shows severe oesophagitis. Which of the following would be the most appropriate next treatment step?
questions.solution:
Indications for fundoplication in this patient would include the fact she is young, has persistent symptoms of reflux despite maximal PPI therapy, and that she has ongoing respiratory symptoms. The use of laparoscopic fundoplication has expanded the range of patients who are now able to undergo surgery. Laparoscopic fundoplication is said to lead to resolution of symptoms in over 9 out of 10 patients who undergo the procedure.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:316 Pg:2217

questions.text:
A 22-year-old woman presents with intermittent diarrhoea, abdominal pain and distension. She has also suffered increasing tiredness and lethargy for the past 6 months. You arrange some investigations: Hb 10.5 g/dlMCV 105 fl
WbC 8.2 * 10*9/L
PLT 135 * 10*9/L
Na+ 140 mmol/l
K+ 3.9 mmol/l
Creatinine 1 mg/dl
Colonoscopy with biopsies shows multiple areas of inflammation, punched out ulcers Barium follow through reveals evidence of severe small bowel inflammation Given the likely diagnosis, which of the following is the biggest risk factor associated with the development of the disease?
questions.solution:
This woman has Crohn’s disease, which has a bimodal distribution, with peak ages of onset 15-30 years and 60-80 years of age. The disease is an inflammatory condition associated with non-caseating granuloma formation and local increases in inflammatory markers, and it is thought that smoking may play a role in increasing the pro-inflammatory state. Use of the oral contraceptive pill however is thought to be associated with greater odds ratio for development or relapse of Crohn’s than smoking.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:319 Pg:2258, 2262, 2263

questions.text: A nurse on duty is being investigated following a needle-stick injury while taking a blood sample from a patient infected with hepatitis B virus, his vaccination status is unknown. Which test will provide the earliest diagnosis of hepatitis B infection in this case?
questions.solution:
Following hepatitis B infection, the first virological marker detectable in the serum is HBsAg. IgM anti-HBc would confirm the diagnosis of an acute infection. HBeAg and anti-HBeAg appear later in the serum. IgG antiHBc indicates past exposure to hepatitis B (HBsAg-negative). Anti-HBsAb is the marker associated with vaccination

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:332 Pg:2360, 2361

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with known cirrhosis secondary to hepatitis C infection attends for review. There is a past history of iv heroin abuse and alcoholism. He has been feeling progressively more unwell during the past 6 months, with weight loss and worsening ascites. He is on long-term sick leave and has been closely monitored by his wife, who maintains there has been no further drug abuse or consumption of alcohol. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis given this clinical picture?
questions.solution:
Elevated a-fetoprotein occurs in 70% of patients with hepatocellular carcinoma. The history of worsening weight loss and ascites occurring over a relatively short period is suggestive of the diagnosis. Risk factors for hepatocellular carcinoma include chronic liver disease, cirrhosis, chronic hepatitis B or C infection and hepatotoxins (alcohol, aflatoxin, anabolic steroid abuse, vinyl chloride exposure), as well as diseases such as α1- antitrypsin deficiency and haemochromatosis. The definitive diagnosis is generally made using ultrasound followed by CT-guided biopsy. Screening is difficult, but surveillance of a -fetoprotein levels may result in the earlier detection of cases. Management, unfortunately, is usually palliative. Even after surgical resection, in the rare cases where this is possible, the survival rate is only 25-30%.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Pg:578, 581-582, 462

questions.text: A homeless male presents with multiple lustreless nails. There is no other skin lesion. What is the most appropriate investigation?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of fungal nail infection is usually based on clinical grounds. Nevertheless a useful, rapid and easy way to confirm the diagnosis is by using a Wood's lamp. Yellow to yellow-green fluorescence is characteristic of fine scales taken from active fungal lesions. However, the sensitivity of this procedure is reduced when patients have taken a recent shower. In this patient, waiting for mycology results is inappropriate as he may well not attend again.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Pg:328-329, 345

questions.text: A 25-year-old man who is complaining of leg weakness. Other than a bout of diarrhoea three weeks ago he has been feeling fit and well and has no significant medical history. On examination there is reduced power in his legs, normal sensation and reduced knee and ankle reflexes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
GUILLAIN-BARRE SYNDROME: FEATURES

Guillain-Barre syndrome describes an immune mediated demyelination of the peripheral nervous system often triggered by an infection (classically Campylobacter jejuni).

The characteristic features of Guillain-Barre syndrome is progressive weakness of all four limbs. The weakness is classically ascending i.e. the lower extremities are affected first, however it tends to affect proximal muscles earlier than the distal ones. Sensory symptoms tend to be mild (e.g. distal paraesthesia) with very few sensory signs. Some patients experience back pain in the initial stages of the illness

Other features

  • areflexia
  • cranial nerve involvement e.g. diplopia
  • autonomic involvement: e.g. urinary retention

Less common findings

  • papilloedema: thought to be secondary to reduced CSF resorption

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:439 Pg:3225-3229

questions.text:
A 77-year-old lady is admitted from home by ambulance. She was found lying on the floor by her home help after suffering a fall. She has a history of hypertension managed with ramipril 10mg PO daily. On examination her temperature is 30.0oC, her BP is 100/50 mmHg, with a pulse of 52/min. She has a fractured left neck of femur.
Bloods; Hb 14.5 g/dl
WbC 4.5 x 10*9/L
PLT 192 * 10*9/L
Na+ 143 mmol/l
K+ 5.3 mmol/l
Creatinine 1.6 mg/dl
Which of the following ECG features is most characteristic of moderate to severe hypothermia?
questions.solution:
Whilst varying degrees of heart block may be seen in association with hypothermia, J waves (Osborn wave) are said to be most characteristic of moderate to severe hypothermia. J waves are best seen in the left chest leads and are described as a dome or hump in the terminal portion of the QRS complex. The size of the J wave is correlated with the degree of hypothermia. Slow atrial fibrillation may also be seen as core temperature falls. Death from ventricular arrhythmias is common in moderate to severe hypothermia

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:235 Pg:1681

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents to the clinic complaining of a lump in the neck which becomes particularly more prominent when she swallows. On examination there is a thyroid nodule at the base of the neck. Leukocyte screening of two other family members who suffered thyroid carcinoma has revealed the ret proto-oncogene. Which type of thyroid carcinoma is linked to the ret-proto-oncogene?
questions.solution:
The ret proto-oncogene encodes for a receptor tyrosine kinase. In medullary thyroid carcinoma the mutation is associated with hyperfunction. Ret is associated with familial cases of medullary thyroid carcinoma and the MEN-2 syndrome. Formerly the condition was screened for with the pentagastrin suppression test, although a DNA probe for ret is now readily available and patients can be screened via a leukocyte sample.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:378, 381 Pg:2717, 2747

choices.text: Long term use of the oral contraceptive pill

questions.text: Chorea is a recognised feature of each of the following disorders EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Chorea refers to brief involuntary, irregular, non-rhythmic, non-repetitive semi-purposeful movement manifested by milkmaid grip, inability to keep the tongue protruded, stuttering gait and clumsiness with dropping objects. Common causes of chorea include:

Hereditary: Huntington's disease, Wilson's disease, ataxia telangiectasia

Infections: Sydenham's chorea, encephalitis

Drugs: levodopa, oestrogen, phenytoin

Metabolic and endocrine: chorea gravidarum, thyrotoxicosis

Vascular: lupus erythematosus, polycythaemia rubra vera (PRV)

Unknown: senile chorea

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:428 Pg:3133, 3136, 3137

questions.text: Crystal-induced acute renal failure can be caused by each of the following EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Due to poor solubility in urine and associated dehydration certain drugs can lead to crystal deposition in the tubules and collecting ducts in the kidneys. This will lead to obstruction, which may present as acute renal failure. Acyclovir is rapidly excreted in urine especially after a bolus intravenous therapy. Birefringent needle-shaped crystals can be seen in urine, particularly using polarised light. Sulfadiazine and sulphamethoxazole which are now being used in higher than usual doses to treat toxoplasmosis in patients with AIDS, can cause crystal deposition in acidic urine. The most common forms of crystals are needle shaped and rosettes. Ingestion of ethylene glycol or rarely high doses of vitamin C results in acute renal failure due to the overproduction and deposition of oxalate crystals. Other drugs include methotrexate and indinavir. Allopurinol possesses the ability to lower serum uric acid levels by inhibiting the conversion of hypoxanthine and xanthine to uric acid. Hypoxanthine and xanthine are water soluble and readily excreted in urine with no tendency for crystal or stone formation.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:310 Pg:2159, 2160

choices.text: In heart failure it indicates poor prognosis
In liver cirrhosis it is due to reduced free water excretion
In the presence of high urea and high serum potassium it is suggestive of Addison's disease
Confusion and depressed conscious level often ensue when serum sodium approaches 120 mmol/l

questions.text: Which one of the following is NOT accurate about hyponatraemia?
questions.solution:
In heart failure, reduced cardiac output will cause reduced renal blood flow, increase of aldosterone secretion and sympathetic activity which results in salt and water retention by the kidneys. ADH is increased in heart failure causing further limitation of free water excretion. Together with the increased thirst in patients with advanced heart failure, this leads to a hyponatraemic state that is a particularly ominous prognostic sign in heart failure. Hyponatraemia in liver disease is typically due to a combination of reduced renal clearance of free water and administration of excessive free water in the form of dextrose solutions. Mineralocorticoid deficiency causes increased urinary clearance of sodium with volume contraction and increased ADH, which reduces free water excretion. The clinical features of hyponatraemia generally manifest when the serum sodium concentration falls to 120 mmol/l or less. Paraproteinaemia causes false hyponatraemia due to displacement of more fluid in the serum, which gives false readings.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Pg:298, 2689, 2070

choices.text: Pain behind the eye on presentation
Swelling of the optic disc on ophthalmoscopic examination of the retina

questions.text: Which one of the following is LEAST helpful in differentiating optic neuritis from papilloedema?
questions.solution:
Optic neuritis is a demyelinating disease of the optic nerve head characterised by acute pain behind the eyes, more on moving the eyes with rapid deterioration of visual acuity and central scotoma. On examination of the retina the changes are difficult to differentiate from papilloedema. Headache and enlargement of the blind spot with normal peripheral field are characteristic of papilloedema. Both conditions can be associated with slurred speech or limb weakness; this is more likely related to the underlying cause. History of recurrent transient arm/leg weakness, cerebellar signs or other deficit is typical of multiple sclerosis that is commonly associated with optic neuritis.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Pg:178, 185, 186

choices.text: Frequently associated with congenital craniocervical malformations
Loss of pain and position sense with preservation of touch and temperature

questions.text: Which one of the following statements concerning syringomyelia/syringobulbia is NOT accurate?
questions.solution:
Syringomyelia is a disorder characterised by slowly progressive enlargement of a fluid filled cyst ‘syrinx' within the cord or medulla oblongata. It can cause damage to the anterior horn cells, the crossing of the spinothalamic tract fibres and the lateral corticospinal tract at the cervical or thoracic level. The clinical features include muscular weakness in the hand and arms, scoliosis, loss of arm reflexes and spastic weakness with bilateral upgoing toes in the lower extremities. ‘Dissociate sensory loss' where there is impaired perception of pain and temperature with preserved light touch and propioception perception in the neck, arm and upper trunk. Extension into the medulla oblongata may cause nystagmus, dysphagia, or wasting of the tongue. Some patients have hydrocephalus or cerebellar signs related to an associated congenital craniocervical malformations (Chiari malformation).

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:434 Pg:3180

choices.text: Hyaline casts are seen in a normal individual
Green urine colour may be due to urinary tract infection (UTI) caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa
Dysmorphic red blood cells indicate glomerular disease
Fat globules on hyaline cast are often encountered in pyelonephritis

questions.text: Each of the following statements is true regarding general urine examination EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
The presence of fat globules on urine microscopy indicates significant proteinuria and probably nephrotic syndrome

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Pg:293-294, 971-973

choices.text: Oral hairy leukoplakia is probably caused by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)
Lymph node biopsy and a blood culture that grew Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare would confirm that HIV is the cause of the generalised lymphadenopathy
Sputum culture is likely to provide diagnostic results for Pneumocystis carinii
CMV infection is the most common cause of retinitis in AIDS

questions.text: Each of the following is true regarding AIDS EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection may have a role in producing hairy leukoplakia. Since Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare (MAI) occurs so rarely in non-pulmonary tissue in association with any disease other than AIDS, its isolation from a lymph node in a previously healthy individual would strongly suggest the diagnosis of AIDS. Other causes of generalised lymphadenopathy include mononucleosis, toxoplasmosis, cytomegalovirus, syphilis and AIDS. Serology and lymph node biopsy are recommended for evaluation of patients with generalised lymphadenopathy. Pneumocystis carinii derived from human specimens cannot be grown in vitro, nor is there a reliable serological test. To establish the diagnosis, the organism must be identified in pulmonary secretions or tissues.

Cytomegalovirus infection is present in almost all AIDS patients, it is by far the most common cause of retinitis among AIDS patients. For reasons that are not currently clear, Kaposi's sarcoma is almost never recognised among AIDS patients who are not homosexual or bisexual.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Pg:1548-1549, 1421, 1430, 1431, 1433

choices.text: Pulmonary haemorrhage usually precedes renal involvement
Vasculitic skin rash is often encountered early in the disease

questions.text: Which one of the following is LEAST suggestive of Goodpasture's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Goodpasture's syndrome is a disease of young males (6:1 male to female ratio), characterised by a triad of pulmonary haemorrhage, glomerulonephritis and anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies (anti-GBM) production. There is a characteristic, continuous, linear pattern of IgG deposition along the capillary wall. It usually begins with pulmonary haemorrhage manifest as haemoptysis, dyspnoea and pulmonary alveolar infiltrate by X-ray, and iron deficiency anaemia. The pulmonary symptoms are followed within days to weeks by development of haematuria, proteinuria and rapid loss of renal function. There is no documented specific skin rash.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:308 Pg:2139

choices.text: AIDS has increased the incidence of MDRTB
Sputum smear for acid-fast bacilli is often positive
Directly observed therapy or supervised therapy is recommended

questions.text: In multiple drug resistant tuberculosis (MDRTB) which one of the following statements is NOT accurate?
questions.solution:
Multiple drug resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) is caused by an isolate of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, which is resistant to two, or more of the first line chemotherapeutic agents usually isoniazid and rifampicin. There has been dramatic change in the epidemiology of TB since the description of AIDS in 1981.

The changes include an increase in the number of primary TB cases reported and also an increase in MDR-TB cases. Sputum smear is positive for acid-fast bacilli in 70% of patients with MDR-TB compared with 50% of patients with pan-sensitive organisms; this mean MDR-TB is more infectious. Directly observed therapy is defined as observation of the patient by a health provider or other responsible person as the patient ingests anti-TB medication

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Pg:1236-1238, 1253-54

choices.text: Viral hepatitis runs a milder course
Acute fatty liver of pregnancy correlates with alcohol consumption prior to pregnancy
Asymptomatic rise of serum alkaline phosphatase warrants further investigations to exclude primary biliary cirrhosis
Cholestasis of pregnancy may recur in subsequent pregnancy

questions.text: Which one of the following statements BEST describes liver diseases during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Viral hepatitis in pregnancy, particularly during the third trimester appears to run a more severe course and is associated with an unusually high incidence of fulminant hepatic failure (FHF) with high fetal and maternal mortality. Vertical transmission of hepatitis B virus infection occurs commonly when then mother contracts the disease during the third trimester. Acute fatty liver develops late in pregnancy, manifests initially by constitutional symptoms often with abdominal pain followed in many instances by hepatic failure with jaundice and encephalitis. The only known treatment is termination of pregnancy. It is not related to alcohol consumption.

Cholestasis occurs late in pregnancy, characterised by pruritus, sometimes followed by jaundice, which typically resolves within two weeks of delivery, but frequently recurs in subsequent pregnancies or with administration of contraceptives.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:339, 466 Pg:2425, 3445

questions.text: Hepatic encephalopathy can be precipitated by each of the following conditions EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Common precipitating factors of hepatic encephalopathy include:

  • Deterioration in hepatic function
  • Drugs: sedatives, diuretics
  • Gastrointestinal haemorrhage
  • Increased dietary proteins
  • Hypokalaemia
  • Infection
  • Azotaemia

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:337 Pg:2413

questions.text: Each of the following conditions is known to cause fatty liver EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Fatty liver disease usually reflects excessive accumulation of triglyceride which may be deposited either in large vacuoles that displace the nucleus or in small droplets with a central nucleus. Small fat droplets are usually associated with liver damage, abnormal liver function and carry a poor prognosis when compared with the large vacuolar type.

Causes include:

  • Large fat globules Small fat droplets
  • Obesity Acute fatty liver of pregnancy
  • Diabetes mellitus Reye's syndrome
  • Malnutrition Tetracycline
  • Corticosteroids Sodium valproate
  • Ethanol ingestion Ethanol ingestion
  • Hypercholesterolaemia is not a condition known to cause fatty liver.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:336 Pg:2401, 2402

choices.text: In human beings ALT (alanine aminotransferase) is exclusively released from liver hepatocytes
Hepatic synthesis of gamma globulin increases in chronic autoimmune liver disease
In the fasting state the esterification pathway is active to provide energy
Ethanol induces hypoglycaemia by direct inhibition of gluconeogenesis

questions.text: Which one of the following is true regarding liver function tests?
questions.solution:
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) enzyme is more specific for hepatobiliary diseases while aspartate aminotransferase may also be elevated in acute myocardial infarction and various muscle diseases. However, ALT is also present in muscle cells and its levels are often elevated whenever there is muscle damage.

The liver produces all circulating proteins except gamma globulins, which are produced by the plasma cells. In the fasting state the oxidative pathway is active to provide an alternative source of energy while in the fed state the esterification pathway is active to store energy as fat. A positive antimitochondrial antibody test does not exclude bile duct obstruction as the cause of obstructive jaundice until other biliary tree tests show no evidence of obstruction.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:329, 335 Pg:2336, 2399.2400

questions.text: Each of the following diseases has an autosomal dominant inheritance EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
While Hemochromatosis is an autosomal recessive, All remaining options are autosomal dominant Inheritance. An autosomal dominant trait is one which is manifested in the heterozygote. Persons affected with an autosomal dominant trait are usually found to have an affected parent. If an affected individual marries a normal person, then on average half their children will be similarly affected.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:407, 457 Pg:2978, 2979, 3374

choices.text: A heterozygous female will transmit the trait to all her sons
All sons born to an affected father and a normal mother will be carriers
Half of paternal uncles will be affected
Half the daughters of a heterozygous mother will be carriers

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding X-linked recessive disorders is true?
questions.solution:
Half of maternal uncles will be affected

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:456 Pg:3359-3360

questions.text: Plasma proteins that increase during the acute phase response include each of the following EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Plasma proteins that increase during the acute phase response include:

  • C-reactive protein
  • Serum amyloid A protein
  • Alpha-1-acid glycoprotein, ceruloplasmin
  • Alpha-macroglobulin
  • Complement components
  • Alpha-1-antitrypsin
  • Fibrinogen
  • Haptoglobin
  • Ferritin

questions.text: Protein losing enteropathy is the LEAST likely manifestation of which one of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
Protein losing enteropathy is a rare syndrome in which absorption is probably normal, but the intestinal wall is abnormally permeable to large molecules (similar to glomerulus in the nephrotic syndrome) and consequently there is excessive loss of protein from the body into the gut. It occurs in a variety of conditions for example, conditions associated with ulceration of the bowel, lymphatic obstruction, intestinal lymphangiectasia and hypertrophic lesion of the bowel (Meneter's disease). In many cases of malabsorption protein exudes into the lumen (coeliac disease and Whipple's disease). Cholera causes secretory diarrhoea with no protein exudation in the gut lumen. The clinical features are similar to those of nephrotic syndrome and the laboratory findings include low albumin, raised a2-globulin and a negative test for protein in urine. The diagnosis can be made by measuring the loss of radioactive albumin into the bowel after intravenous injection.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:318 Pg:2256

questions.text: Precocious puberty in boys is a feature of each of the following disorders EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Precocious puberty is defined as the development of sexual maturation before the age of nine in boys (eight in girls) in addition to the development of secondary sexual characteristics. It is accompanied by accelerated skeletal maturation and linear growth with premature closure of the long bone epiphyses resulting in short stature as an adult. It is divided into two types:

  • True precocious pubertyis caused by premature secretion of gonadotropins. Testicular androgens and sperm production are stimulated by gonadotropins and result in viriulization and an increase in testicular size.

Causes include:

Idiopathic precocious puberty CNS lesions affecting the posterior hypothalamus such as craniopharyngiomas, haematomas, hydrocephalus, neurofibromas, tuberous sclerosis, post-encephalitic lesion HCG secreting tumours (hepatoblastoma) Primary hypothyroidism; it is probably due to direct stimulation of FSH receptors by high serum TSH concentration. Testicular enlargement and other features regress with thyroxine therapy

  • Precocious pseudopubertyresults from secretion of androgens from the adrenal gland or testes. Excessive androgens result in virilization, but sperm production is not stimulated and the testes remain small.

Causes include:

Adrenocortical hyperfunction (congenital adrenal hyperplasia, virilizing adrenocortical tumour) Leydig cell tumour McCune-Albright syndrome (hyperpigmentation, polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, multinodular goitre and other glandular hyperfunction) In gigantism, hypogonadism is frequently present leading to delayed epiphysial closure and thus a more prolonged growth period. Klinefelter's syndrome is the most common cause of primary testicular failure resulting in impairment of both spermatogenesis and testosterone production

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:384 Pg:2774

choices.text: Typically occurs in the first week after delivery
Spontaneous recovery is expected in 90% of cases

questions.text: The following statements with regard to postpartum thyroiditis are true EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Postpartum thyroiditis may occur in 5% of postpartum women, at least three months after delivery and characterised by two phases:

  1. The hyperthyroid phase (lasting 2-4 weeks) occurs alone in half of the cases with mild symptoms and may be associated with a small painless goitre. It can be differentiated from Graves' disease by the absence of thyroid stimulating antibodies and a low radioactive iodine uptake.
  2. The hypothyroid phase (lasting 4-12 weeks) after delivery, which may or may not be preceded by the hyperthyroid phase.

It is 3 times more common in patients with type 1 DM.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:377 Pg:2709

choices.text: Carcino-embryonic antigen (CEA) is not a reliable screening test
The risk of carcinoma is higher if the colitis is confined to the left colon
Mucosal dysplasia on rectal biopsy is associated with the likelihood of carcinoma elsewhere in the bowel

questions.text: Which one of the following statements regarding adenocarcinoma of the colon complicating ulcerative colitis is INCORRECT
questions.solution:
The overall prevalence of cancer in all patients with ulcerative colitis is 3%-5%. For those with pancolitis and disease duration greater than 10 years, the risk is 10-20 times greater than that of the general population. The prognosis of carcinoma of the colon developing in patients with ulcerative colitis tends to be worse than that developing in the absence of colitis because the diagnosis is often delayed because the symptoms of bleeding and diarrhoea may be attributed initially to a recurrence of colitis. The lesions are often multifocal and display a higher grade of malignancy. Carcinoembryonic antigen is not a reliable screening test for early cases of colonic carcinoma.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:319 Pg:2275, 2276

choices.text: Most commonly found in the colon
Carcinoid syndrome can manifest in the absence of liver metastases
Aortic stenosis is the most frequent heart valve disease in advanced carcinoid tumour
Carcinoid flush is often associated with an instant rise in diastolic blood pressure

questions.text: Which one of the following clinical findings is true regarding carcinoid tumour?
questions.solution:
Carcinoid tumours arise from enterochromaffin (Kulchitsky) cells that are located predominantly in the gastrointestinal mucosa. They are most commonly found in the small bowel. Clinical carcinoid syndrome is usually associated with carcinoid tumour that has spread to the liver. Tumours in sites such as the lung and the ovary can produce carcinoid syndrome without evident hepatic metastasis. Presumably the liver clears mediators released from the tumour and this clearance is bypassed by liver metastasis or when the tumour does not drain in the portal system. The syndrome is characterised by recurrent episodes of flushing, diarrhoea and hypotension. In longstanding cases right-sided endocardial fibrosis, pulmonary artery stenosis, and tricuspid regurgitation might lead to progressive heart failure.

Diagnosis is based upon clinical suspicion and markedly elevated urinary 5-hydroxyindol acetic acid excretion. Chocolate, bananas and tomatoes may cause increased excretion of 5-hydroxyindol acetic acid.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Pg:603-604

questions.text: Each of the following metabolic conditions is associated with increased incidence of primary hepatocellular carcinoma EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Hepatocellular carcinoma usually complicates chronic liver disease secondary to chronic alcoholism or viral hepatitis. Metabolic disorders, which may be complicated by hepatocellular carcinomas, include the following:

  • Haemochromatosis
  • α1-antitrypsin deficiency
  • Hereditary tyrosinosis
  • Glycogen storage disease type 1

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:253 Pg:578, 462, 1331

questions.text: Causes of acute pancreatitis include each of the following EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Common causes of acute pancreatitis include alcoholism and biliary tract disease. Other causes include:

  • Trauma
  • Infections (Coxsackie virus, mumps)
  • Metabolic: hyperlipidaemia, hyperparathyroidism, NOT hypoparathyroidism
  • Drugs: corticosteroids, azathioprine, thiazide, frusemide, phenformin, oral contraceptives and tetracycline
  • SLE, PAN
  • Familial

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:341 Pg:2438

questions.text: Each of the following infections/disorders are associated with the genus Chlamydia EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
The genus Chlamydia contains two species, C. psittaci and C. trachomatis. The former is a ubiquitous cause of infection in birds and lower mammals with human beings as occasional accidental hosts. It could cause serious pneumonic disease when transmitted to humans. C. trachomatis causes ocular infection (trachoma) which is regarded as the commonest cause of blindness in developing countries. C. trachomatis types L1, L2 and L3 cause procto-colitis and painful enlargement of the inguinal lymph glands (lymphogranuloma venereum). Reiter's syndrome is a disorder of unknown aetiology; it is characterised by a triad of arthritis, conjunctivitis and urethritis. In the postvenereal type both Chlamydia and Mycoplasma are implicated. Q (Query) fever is caused by Coxiella burnetii, a Rickettsia- like organism. The clinical features of the illness are protean ranging from subclinical infection to fatal encephalitis and endocarditis.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Pg:1317-1319

questions.text: A patient presents with congestive heart failure. Which drug may be effective in reducing mortality?
questions.solution:
Reduction in left ventricular afterload has been shown to prolong survival rates in patients with congestive heart failure. Vasodilators such as angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, by inhibiting the formation of angiotensin II in the coronary arteries, are thus effective. Digoxin reduces the risk of death due to heart failure, but overall cardiovascular mortality is similar to that with a placebo. Aspirin is useful only in cases of coronary occlusion or myocardial infarction

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:253 Pg:1773-1775

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, who is receiving fortnightly intramuscular injections for rheumatoid arthritis, presents with sore throat, cough and tingling and numbness in her hands and feet. Blood tests show pancytopenia. What medication is she most likely to be on for rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Gold (sodium aurothiomalate) is given by deep intramuscular injection. Initially given weekly, the injections are spaced to fortnightly and then monthly. Any side-effect that develops is potentially serious and precludes further therapy. Peripheral neuropathy, skin reactions, nephrotic syndrome and pulmonary fibrosis may also occur as adverse reactions to gold treatment. All the other medications (DMARDs, disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs) are usually given orally although methotrexate can also be administered via the intra-muscular route.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Pg:334, 347, 824, 2588

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman who underwent excision of a meningioma 3 months ago, has developed severe bruising and menorrhagia. She has also noticed swelling of her gums and progressive malaise and weakness. Which drug could be responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Patients are frequently given prophylactic treatment with antiepileptics such as phenytoin following neurosurgical procedures. Side-effects of phenytoin include gum hypertrophy, folate deficiency, aplastic anaemia, osteomalacia and neuropathy.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:418 Pg:3063

questions.text: A 29-year-old man on antituberculous therapy complains of tingling and numbness in his hands and feet. Which antitubercular drug may be causing this problem?
questions.solution:
Isoniazid causes peripheral neuropathy, the risk of which is increased in slow acetylators and in those with other risk factors such as malnutrition, alcoholism, diabetes and HIV infection. Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) is given both prophylactically and, at a higher dose, to treat established neuropathy. Streptomycin causes ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity, especially in the elderly. The main adverse effects of ethambutol are loss of visual acuity, restriction of visual fields and colour blindness. Pyrazinamide and rifampicin are hepatotoxic.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Pg:1273, 1274

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman on antituberculous treatment with rifampicin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, ethambutol and pyridoxine has been taking the oral contraceptive pill regularly but now suddenly finds she is pregnant. Which drug could have resulted in failure of the oral contraceptive treatment?
questions.solution:
Rifampicin is a potent hepatic enzyme inducer that increases the metabolism of many drugs, including all the steroid hormones. Barrier contraceptives must be used during treatment with rifampicin and for 4-8 weeks after a course of rifampicin is completed.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Pg:425, 1255-1256, 1049

choices.text: Punctuate basophilic stippling on peripheral blood film examination
Membranous glomerulonephritis as the primary kidney lesion

questions.text: Which one of the following features is MOST characteristic of lead poisoning?
questions.solution:
Lead poisoning could occur through ingestion, inhalation and direct skin contact. Numerous occupations entail potentially significant exposure, e.g. miners, welders, storage battery workers. Pottery workers are particularly heavily exposed. The exact pathogenesis of lead colic remains uncertain. In part it appears to be due to the direct effect of lead on intestinal smooth muscles. Lead interferes with a variety of red cell enzymes leading to red cell abnormalities which include punctuate basophilic stippling and clover leaf morphology. The peripheral neuropathy, which is seen in adult patients, is almost always exclusively motor. Interstitial nephritis is the characteristic lesion in the kidneys. A gingival blue-black or grey line is found in up to 20% of adult patients but is infrequent in children.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Pg:379, 717, 720

choices.text: Reduces protein C levels in the blood
Chronic use is often associated with osteoporosis
An initial loading dose is given because it has a short half-life (3 hours)

questions.text: Which one of the following statements BEST describes warfarin?
questions.solution:
Warfarin competitively inhibits carboxylation of vitamin K dependent factors. Vitamin K dependent factors include: factor II; VII; IX; X (‘reverse the year 1972') and protein C. The half-life of warfarin is approximately 44 hours. The level of warfarin in breast milk is too little to be of any clinical significance. Autoimmune thrombocytopenia and osteoporosis are side-effects more often encountered with heparin rather than warfarin therapy

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Pg:852-853

choices.text: Exacerbation and prolongation of the attack
Complete remission of symptoms within a few days of treatment
Reduction of uric acid levels to normal within a week of commencement of treatment

questions.text: Treatment of an acute attack of gout with allopurinol may result in which of the following?
questions.solution:
NSAIDs in high doses are the drugs of choice in acute gout. Allopurinol is used when the attacks are frequent and severe, despite dietary changes, or associated with renal impairment or when the patient finds NSAIDs or colchicine difficult to tolerate. Starting at 100 mg and the building up to 300 mg or more is recommended to avoid exacerbation of symptoms. Initiation of treatment during an attack can exacerbate and prolong the episode; hence it is prudent to wait until the attack settles. Treatment should be started with a low starting dose (100 mg/day) or by concurrent administration of oral colchicine for the first few weeks. Higher doses may exacerbate the attack rather than cause renal impairment.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:365 Pg:2632-2633

questions.text: At therapeutic doses, which of the following are side-effects of aminophylline?
questions.solution:
Aminophylline is a severe irritant of the gastrointestinal tract and causes nausea and vomiting. The central nervous system side-effects include jitteriness, seizures and coma. Ventricular and supraventricular arrhythmias and hypotension are common in severe overdose (> 25 µg/ml). Profound hypokalaemia is common in overdose with theophylline compounds and may be fatal unless intravenous potassium is given.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:281 Pg:249, 324, 1965

choices.text: Liver function tests, prothrombin time and INR estimations

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman is brought to casualty having ingested 20 tablets of paracetamol 8 hours earlier. What should her immediate management consist of?
questions.solution:
Activated charcoal is useful if given within one hour of the paracetamol overdose. Liver function tests, INR and prothrombin time will be normal, as liver damage may not manifest until 24 hours or more after ingestion. Plasma paracetamol levels are not required and will only delay management; in any case, the amount of paracetamol ingested is known. N-Acetylcysteine is recommended in all cases where the paracetamol overdose exceeds 150 mg/kg body weight. The antidote of choice is thus intravenous N-acetylcysteine, which provides complete protection against toxicity if given within 10 hours of the overdose; its efficacy declines thereafter.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:333 Pg:2369-2371

choices.text: It is combined with sulfamethoxazole for synergistic reasons
It requires estimation of serum levels to assess therapeutic efficacy
It may cause marrow depression and microcytic anaemia

questions.text: Which of the following statements relates to the trimethoprim?
questions.solution:
Trimethoprim acts by inhibiting dihydrofolate reductase, an enzyme that is important in the division of cells. The combination, co-trimoxazole, is commonly used to treat urinary tract infections and respiratory illnesses. The synergistic combination makes it a powerful bactericidal combination agent. No specific hepatic toxicity has been reported with trimethoprim. Megaloblastic anaemia may occur due to folate deficiency. Serum levels are rarely used to maintain a course of trimethoprim, and serum levels have no correlation with guiding dosage.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Pg:1054

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman has an acute attack of migraine. She is given a subcutaneous injection of sumatriptan, which relieves her symptoms. What is the drug's most likely mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Sumatriptan is a selective 5-HT (5-hydroxytryptamine, serotonin) receptor agonist used to treat migraine in the acute phase. It acts in both classical and common migraine. It is effective orally, sublingually, by the subcutaneous route or by nasal spray. The mode of action of sumatriptan includes vasoconstriction of the cranial arteries and it may also act directly on neurotransmitters involved in the pain cascade within the trigeminal system.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:422 Pg:3100-3102
